NAM.name: Proper Noun
NAM.description: Names of specific people, places, organizations, etc.

VRB.name: Verb
VRB.description: Verbs including inflected forms, participles, and auxiliaries

ADV.name: Adverb
ADV.description: Words that modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs

DET.name: Determiner
DET.description: Words that introduce nouns (the, a, this, some) including articles

CNJ.name: Conjunction
CNJ.description: Words that connect clauses or phrases

PRT.name: Particle
PRT.description: Function words that do not fit other categories cleanly

PHR.name: Phrase
PHR.description: Multi-word expressions treated as lexical units

IDM.name: Idiom
IDM.description: Expressions whose meanings are not compositionally predictable

SYM.name: Symbol
SYM.description: Non-alphabetic symbols, letters, or punctuation used lexically

MLT.name: Multiple
MLT.description: Entries with multiple parts of speech not yet disambiguated

ABRV.name: Abbreviation
ABRV.description: Sense is an abbreviation, initialism, or acronym of a longer form. Useful for “base-form only” dictionaries or when filtering short‐form entries.

INFL.name: Inflected Form
INFL.description: Sense is an inflected form of a lemma (plural, tense, degree, etc.), as opposed to a base lemma form.

ALTH.name: Alternative Form
ALTH.description: Sense is an alternative form, spelling, or variant of another word. Similar to INFL but for spelling variants rather than grammatical forms.

REGS.name: Register
REGS.description: Stylistic or formality properties of usage.

REUP.name: euphemistic
REUP.description: Euphemistic expression, often avoiding a taboo term.

RLIT.name: literary
RLIT.description: Literary or elevated style, often in written texts.

RNST.name: nonstandard
RNST.description: Nonstandard usage that deviates from prescriptive norms.

TEMP.name: Temporal status
TEMP.description: Diachronic status of usage (current vs historical).

TARC.name: archaic
TARC.description: Largely outdated; occasionally encountered in older texts.

TOBS.name: obsolete
TOBS.description: No longer in normal use; only historical or highly marked uses.

TDAT.name: dated
TDAT.description: Once normal, now perceived as somewhat old-fashioned.

THIS.name: historical
THIS.description: Used in historical contexts, often for institutions or concepts that no longer exist.

TRAR.name: rare
TRAR.description: Rare or infrequently used in contemporary language.

REGN.name: Usage region
REGN.description: Geographic regions where the term is in use.

ENNZ.name: English (New Zealand)
ENNZ.description: Usage typical of New Zealand English.

ENZA.name: English (South Africa)
ENZA.description: Usage typical of South African English.

SPRG.name: Spelling region
SPRG.description: Regional orthographic norm for this written form.

SPIN.name: Indian spelling
SPIN.description: Follows Indian / South-Asian English spelling conventions.

NSND.name: Nonstandard type
NSND.description: Nonstandard forms such as leetspeak or common misspellings.

NMIS.name: misspelling
NMIS.description: Common or recognized misspelling of another word.

IDIM.name: idiom
IDIM.description: Fixed or semi-fixed expression whose meaning is not predictable from the meanings of its individual components.

PRVB.name: proverb
PRVB.description: Short, commonly known saying that expresses a general truth or piece of advice.

PPHR.name: prepositional phrase
PPHR.description: Phrase centered on an adposition (preposition/postposition), plus its complement.

NPHR.name: noun phrase
NPHR.description: Phrase built around a noun or pronoun, possibly with determiners and modifiers.

VPHR.name: verb phrase
VPHR.description: Phrase built around a verb, including auxiliaries and complements.

APHR.name: adverbial phrase
APHR.description: Phrase functioning as an adverbial (modifying a verb, clause, or sentence), whether or not it is headed by an adverb.

SIMP.name: simple
SIMP.description: No clear internal morphological structure is identified beyond the base. Either no etymology template was recognized, or components did not produce derivational structure.

COMP.name: compound
COMP.description: Form is analyzed as a compound of two or more bases, none of which is uniquely designated as “the” base word. All components are peers.

PREF.name: prefixed
PREF.description: One or more prefixes attach to a base. Prefixes typically have trailing hyphens in normalized components (e.g., "un-").

SUFF.name: suffixed
SUFF.description: One or more suffixes attach to a base. Suffixes typically have leading hyphens in normalized components (e.g., "-ness").

AFFX.name: affixed
AFFX.description: Both prefix(es) and suffix(es) occur around a base, or otherwise the structure is best treated as a combined affixal derivation.

CIRC.name: circumfixed
CIRC.description: A special case of affixed morphology where a logically single affix is split into a prefix-like and suffix-like part (circumfix). Not all scanners will distinguish this from AFFX; the core type exists for languages where circumfixes are explicit.

DMATH.name: mathematics
DMATH.description: Mathematics, set theory, logic, algebra, geometry, calculus.

DANAT.name: anatomy
DANAT.description: Anatomy, body parts, and physiological structures.

DLING.name: linguistics
DLING.description: Linguistics, grammar, phonetics, and language study.

DGAMB.name: gaming
DGAMB.description: Gambling, card games, board games, and recreational gaming.

DGAST.name: gastronomy
DGAST.description: Cooking, food, beverages, and culinary arts.
